intro: Erythea armata var. microcarpa, commonly known as the small-fruited erythea, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and palmate leaves with five to seven lobes. Its small, pale pink to white flowers bloom in summer, and the fruit is a capsule that contains numerous tiny seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks.
